title: ‘We need bigger ships’: Polish security agency wants new fleet to counter ‘Russian threat’
text:
‘We need bigger ships’: Polish security agency wants new fleet to counter ‘Russian threat’ Published time: 11 Feb, 2017 00:53 Get short URL Polish submarine ORP SEP © Kacper Pempel / Reuters Poland's National Security Bureau, the BNN, has unveiled a new development plan for the country's fleet. It envisages defending against a “Russian threat” – with ships capable of operating far from native shores. 
In a report published Friday, titled "The Strategic Concept Of Maritime Safety of the Republic of Poland," the BNN states that “Polish seafaring interests are located all over the world’s maritime arena.” The authors recommend building up the Polish navy so that it may have a limited, but global, ability to project power that may be consistently demonstrated far from its territorial waters, working together with allied fleets. Read more US troops hold joint drills in Poland to ensure ‘unlikely attack from East even more unlikely’ 
“It should be emphasized that a key component of deterrence against potential, direct and serious external threat is the inevitability of an adequate response from NATO, which Poland must constantly seek, both through the appropriate diplomatic channels, as well as the active participation of the Republic of Poland’s naval forces in the projects and activities of the Alliance,” the report reads. This would make Poland a more important member of the NATO alliance in the face of the perceived threat from Russia, which is a core theme in the report. “Also important is the fact of progressive militarization of the Baltic Sea, which is mostly the result of Russia’s actions,” the BNN’s experts claim. 
In addition to military activity in the Baltic Sea, Russian control over resources such as natural gas is highlighted as a threat, giving Moscow leverage over the countries which import it. 
READ MORE: ‘It's NATO - not Russia - that has deployed tanks to Poland & Baltic States' – George Galloway 
The report considers the possibility of a Russian-provoked conflict in the Baltics in which Sweden and Finland, who are not part of NATO, will also be attacked. In this scenario, Polish and NATO vessels could be used to blockade Russian ports, but will need a significant overhaul of their capabilities. “If we are to combat the threats from the air, from the sea and from the water, the [existing] corvettes are not able to fully handle this,” BNN deputy head Dariusz Gwizdała told the Polish Press Agency, commenting on the report. “Basically, their size doesn’t allow, among other things, installing proper reconnaissance systems and weaponry. Because of this we’ve come to the conclusion that we need bigger ships.” Read more 
The BNN also considers air superiority crucial to any conflict in the region and recommends that its fleet be integrated with air forces.Russian Navy veterans have responded to the paper with skepticism. “The naval force of the Republic of Poland is, to put it mildly, one of the most aging [in the world],” former Russian Baltic Fleet Commander, Admiral Vladimir Valuyev, told RIA Novosti.Valuyev reminded that it was the Soviet Union that provided Poland with the core of its 20th century fleet, with Moscow handing 23 vessels, including destroyers, submarines and missile boats in 1946 alone. While the objectives of the fleet, which was to guard the Baltic Sea against the Soviets’ NATO adversaries, took a 180-degree turn with Poland joining NATO in March 1999, only a fraction of the battleworthy ships remained. Warsaw purchased some of the newer ships from NATO countries, and vessels of the same class have by now been decommissioned in the countries of origin.Following the conflict in Ukraine, and Crimea’s reunification with Russia in 2014, NATO has escalated up its military buildup close to Russia’s borders, citing the alleged aggression coming from Moscow. Thousands of troops and heavy weaponry have been deployed to the Baltic States, Poland and southeastern Europe. 
READ MORE: 10 years on, Putin’s Munich speech continues to resonate 
Russia has consistently warned against such moves by NATO, which particularly intensified in the last few months of Barack Obama's presidency. Having denied the accusations of being an aggressor, Moscow has stressed it is being forced to take countermeasures to protect its national interests. Arms and equipment: US troops 'woo' Latvian border guards after NATO drills come to end https://t.co/a94kAaiuUJ pic.twitter.com/HQjcBwiuu5 — RT (@RT_com) 10 февраля 2017 г. 
“It’s obvious that the steps by NATO gravely increase the risk of incidents" between the alliance and Russian forces, Russian Deputy Foreign Minister Aleksey Meshkov said in an interview with RIA Novosti. "For the first time since World War II we see German soldiers along our borders," he added.
